Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: United Parcel Service, Inc. agreed to pay $2 million to nearly 90 current and former employees to resolve a nationwide disability discrimination lawsuit filed in 2009 by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission as well as to conciliate related administrative charges.
Info Source: https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/8-8-17.cfm
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: United Parcel Service, Inc. and the United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of California entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement in which UPS agreed to forfeit $40 million in payments it has received from illicit online pharmacies and to implement a compliance program designed to ensure that illegal online pharmacies will not be able to use UPS's services to distribute drugs.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/usao-ndca/pr/ups-agrees-forfeit-40-million-payments-illicit-online-pharmacies-shipping-services

Description: The award was upheld by a state appeals court: 148 A.D.3d 574, 49 N.Y.S.3d 690 (App Div, 1st Dept 2017)
Private Litigation Case Title: Rivera v. United Parcel Serv., Inc.
Info Source: https://law.justia.com/cases/new-york/appellate-division-first-department/2017/303092-08-3484-3483.html

Description: Racial discrimination. A state jury awarded $5.3 million to a group of black UPS drivers who said they were subjected to a hostile work environment. The verdict was upheld by a state appeals court: https://law.justia.com/cases/kentucky/court-of-appeals/2018/2016-ca-001161-mr.html
Private Litigation Case Title: Barber v. United Parcel Serv., Inc
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/784791/ky-jury-awards-ups-workers-5-3m-after-effigy-hanging

Private Litigation Case Title: Pruitt, et al v. Utd Parcel Svc, et al
Info Source: 2004 Jury Verdicts LEXIS 49860

Private Litigation Case Title: Ibarra v. United Parcel Serv. Inc.
Info Source: https://www.businessinsurance.com/article/20130226/NEWS06/130229859/Jury-awards-former-UPS-driver-$600,000-in-gender-case

Description: A group of deaf employees alleged that UPS discriminated against them by denying promotional opportunities and communications devices. In 2003 a settlement was reached in which class members received $5.8 million and their lawyers received $4.1 million (see separate entry). A dispute over UPS policies with regard to hiring deaf workers as drivers was handled separately. After drawn-out proceedings, the matter was resolved in 2010 in a settlement in which UPS agreed to change its hearing protocols. There were no additional damage payments offered to class members but their lawyers received $5.25 million in legal fees for this portion of the case.
Private Litigation Case Title: Bates, et al v. United Parcel Service (2nd part)
Info Source: https://www.clearinghouse.net/detail.php?id=10666&search=source%7Cgeneral%3BcaseName%7Cbates%20v.%20united%3Borderby%7CfilingYear%3B

Description: A group of deaf employees alleged that UPS discriminated against them by denying promotional opportunities and communications devices. A settlement was reached in which class members received $5.8 million and their lawyers received $4.1 million. A dispute over UPS policies with regard to hiring deaf workers as drivers was handled separately (see other entry).
Private Litigation Case Title: Bates, et al v. United Parcel Service (1st part)
Info Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2003/07/22/us/ups-settles-bias-lawsuit-brought-by-deaf-workers.html
https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/12-21-18b.cfm
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Info Source: https://www.faa.gov/about/office_org/headquarters_offices/agc/practice_areas/enforcement/reports/

Description: UPS agreed to pay $4 million to resolves multistate allegations that certain employees violated false claims act laws by recording inaccurate delivery times on packages sent via next-day delivery services by government customers. That resulted in premium-priced packages that appeared to be delivered by their guaranteed commitment times when, in fact, they were not.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20170716110516/https://ag.ny.gov/press-release/ag-schneiderman-announces-4-million-settlement-shipping-giant-ups-overcharging
https://nj.gov/oag/newsreleases15/pr20150519a.html

Description: United Parcel Service, Inc. agreed to pay $1.3 million as part of a settlement resolving allegations that the company knowingly permitted package delivery trucks in serious disrepair to be driven and operated by UPS employees throughout New York State.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20150905194700/http://www.ag.ny.gov/press-release/ag-schneiderman-announces-crackdown-dangerous-ups-trucks-secures-13-million-settlement

Description: United Parcel Service Inc. agreed to pay the United States $8.4 million to resolve allegations that it overcharged federal agencies for package delivery services under a General Services Administration (GSA) contract.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/united-states-settles-united-parcel-service-overcharging-federal-agencies-under-general
https://www.eeoc.gov/eeoc/newsroom/release/9-17-19a.cfm
Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Description: New York City and New York State prevailed in a suit against United Parcel Service for knowingly violating State and Federal laws prohibiting the shipment of contraband cigarettes. UPS had appealed a $246M judgment. In a 2-1 decision an appeals court affirmed the liability finding but changed the award to $98 million.
Info Source: https://www1.nyc.gov/site/law/news/029-19/appeals-court-upholds-ruling-against-united-parcel-service-shipping-illegal-untaxed-cigarettes
https://web.archive.org/web/20090813022804/http://eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement12-03.html
https://web.archive.org/web/20090813021046/http://eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement09-03.html
https://web.archive.org/web/20090813021420/http://eeoc.gov/litigation/settlements/settlement07-03.html
https://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=14596
https://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=24594
